performance.response: if P then Q; P; therefore Q

Modus ponens is the basic valid inference rule that lets you get a conclusion whenever you have an implication and its antecedent. Formally it is written as a rule schema:

From
1. P → Q
2. P
infer
3. Q

In sequent/derivation notation: {P → Q, P} ⊢ Q. In semantic terms (entailment): {P → Q, P} ⊨ Q — whenever the two premises are true in a model, Q is true in that model. In natural-deduction terminology this rule is often called implication-elimination (→E).

Intuitively and truth-functionally: the material conditional P → Q is false only when P is true and Q is false. So if P → Q is true and P is true, the only possibility left is that Q is true, hence Q follows. Example: “If it is raining, the streets are wet” (P → Q); “It is raining” (P); therefore “The streets are wet” (Q).

Modus ponens applies equally in propositional and first-order logic (with P and Q replaced by arbitrary formulas). It is a valid (truth-preserving) and central rule of deduction, but it requires that both premises be accepted; it does not tell you how to establish those premises.

An argument form is valid when it is impossible for all the premises to be true and the conclusion false at the same time. Modus ponens has the form "If P then Q" and "P", therefore "Q" (symbolically: ((P→Q) ∧ P) ⊢ Q). By the meaning of the conditional, the only way "P→Q" could be false is if P is true and Q is false. But one premise of modus ponens is that P is true, and the other is that P→Q is true, so the situation "P true and Q false" is ruled out. Therefore in every case (every truth assignment or possible world) where the premises are true, Q must also be true. That truth‑preserving property is exactly what makes modus ponens a valid deductive argument.

Modus ponens is one of the simplest and most important rules of deductive logic. It tells you how to validly move from a conditional statement and the truth of its antecedent to the truth of its consequent.

What it says
- Formally: From P → Q and P you may conclude Q.
- Symbolic compact forms: ((P → Q) ∧ P) ⊢ Q or {P → Q, P} ⊢ Q.
- In words: “If P then Q. P is true. Therefore Q is true.”

Why it is valid
- Truth-preserving: under the usual (classical) truth conditions for the material conditional, if both premises (P → Q and P) are true, Q must be true. There is no possible classical truth assignment in which the two premises are true and the conclusion false.
- Intuitively: a conditional promises that whenever P holds, Q follows; asserting P activates that promise, so you may infer Q.

Logical role and notation
- In natural deduction systems, modus ponens is the implication-elimination rule (often called →-elimination or “apply the rule”). In proof calculi it is the basic allowed inference step that discharges a conditional by supplying its antecedent.
- It is also the core step behind forward-chaining in rule-based systems: given a rule “if condition then conclusion” and a known condition, the system derives the conclusion.

Examples
- Simple everyday example: “If it is raining, the street will be wet. It is raining. Therefore the street is wet.”
- Mathematical use: If n is even then n^2 is even; n is even; therefore n^2 is even.

Common confusions and related patterns
- Affirming the consequent (invalid): From P → Q and Q infer P is not valid. Example: “If it rains then the street is wet; the street is wet; therefore it rained” — invalid.
- Denying the antecedent (invalid): From P → Q and ¬P infer ¬Q is invalid.
- Modus tollens (valid, related): From P → Q and ¬Q infer ¬P. This is a different valid inference that denies the consequent to deny the antecedent.

Applications
- Mathematics and formal proofs: used to apply proven implications.
- Automated theorem proving and logic programming: engines repeatedly apply modus ponens to derive consequences of rules.
- Expert systems and forward-chaining rule systems: production rules are applied exactly in this way.
- Legal and other normative reasoning: conditional rules plus factual findings yield conclusions and obligations.

Limits and caveats
- Modus ponens relies on the logic’s conditional behaving as expected (classical material implication or suitable conditional). In non-classical systems (e.g., some formulations of quantum logic or relevance logics) the usual form may not hold or may require different interpretation.
- Natural-language “if” can carry causal, probabilistic, or conversational content that is not captured by the material conditional; applying modus ponens requires that the conditional be understood as a logical implication, not merely a loose causal claim.

Historical and philosophical notes
- The rule goes back to ancient logic (Stoics) and was formalized in medieval and modern logic. Philosophers have treated it as a core principle of deductive reasoning; Kant called the form analytic in character because the conclusion is already implicit in the premises.

In short, modus ponens is the basic, truth-preserving rule that lets you apply a conditional when its antecedent is known, and it underpins much of formal and applied reasoning in logic, mathematics, computer science, and AI.
